GeneralBackground.Overview: SSL certificates encrypt communication between a server and a client using public key infrastructure (PKI). Certificate Transparency (CT) logs are public records of SSL issuance used to detect misuse.

EducationalLevels.Child: SSL is like a secret code to send safe messages. CT logs are lists showing who got the code.
EducationalLevels.Teenager: SSL scrambles messages for safety; CT logs let you verify if someone is pretending to be another.
EducationalLevels.Undergrad: SSL uses PKI for authentication. CT logs record all certificates to improve transparency.
EducationalLevels.GradStudent: SSL ensures secure communication using asymmetric cryptography. CT logs provide publicly auditable certificate issuance records.
EducationalLevels.Professor: SSL certificates (X.509) ensure authentication via asymmetric encryption. CT logs, structured as Merkle trees, offer immutable transparency for PKI infrastructure.

ProductDescription.Summary: The SSL Catalog gathers and structures data from CT logs, resulting in a large database of SSL certificates issued by trusted Certificate Authorities.

DataCollection.Method: Unlike other Dataprovider products, SSL data is not retrieved by crawling but appears in CT logs when a certificate is issued.
DataCollection.Frequency: Dependent on certificate validity (e.g., 3 months or 1 year)

TechnicalBackground.Notes: Data is fetched directly from CT logs and parsed into structured formats including certificate metadata, hostnames, and issuer info.
